description: Numbers n such that sum of proper divisors of n exceeds that of all smaller numbers.
links: T. D. Noe and Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000 (first 372 terms from T. D. Noe)
example: Contribution from _William A. Tedeschi_, Aug 19 2010: (Start)-- 12: 1+2+3+4+6 = 1613: 1 = 114: 1+2+7 = 1015: 1+3+5 = 916: 1+2+4+8 = 1617: 1 = 1-- 18: 1+2+3+6+9 = 21As 12 had the previous (earliest) highest it is listed, then since 18 has the new highest, it is listed. (End)
mathematica: A={}; m=-1; For[ i=1, i<10000, i++, t=Apply[ Plus, Divisors[ i ] ]-i; If[ t>m, m=t; AppendTo[ A, i ] ] ]; A
author: _J. Lowell_
